text: Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany? Doctor: And so what they’ve done different than we do here is they report it on their experience. So they’re like we treated these six-hundred people, people with different stage, and different things, and they try to give some data about how the people live, what was their survival, and they showed you know tumor shrinking, and their response rate. And so overall that Gestalt, that’s a German word. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That looks, looks really good, I think. And then they collaborate with this gentleman that I have experience with in Turkey, seeing the data presented. I mean you share but you know some of the data that shows incredible responses to these. So I think part of it depends on how active your cancer is for this study, for this, this for the PSMA. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: And then if you see the result, you would know probably in two months if you saw the results? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: And then if you didn’t see results, would you go to a bone marrow? Patient: Right. Doctor: Well, we could do chemotherapy still. We could do a trial of chemotherapy. Uh you know the bone marrow transplant to me, you know, it’s a trial that I’m doing. You know it’s the only treatment I know of that cures cancer. So if you take people with bad leukemia and bad lymphoma you can cure them- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: by giving them somebody else’s immune system. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Patient: Huh, I would say, sometimes it’s a five on my neck, especially when I turn it. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And on your (voice) Patient: Or bend it backwards. The right side ain’t bothering me. It’s just that one that, well, the one that the screw came loose. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, any numbness or tingling? Patient: What? In my neck? Doctor: Your arms, your legs. Patient: No. And the only other thing that now and then is my shoulder blade from the day, from the first day that I was operated on. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, all the new studies are like hey, radium and phone a friend, you know, radium and Xtandi, radium and chemo, radium and whatever. So, they’re all in studies but not standard of care yet. I’m gonna pause right there and see how you guys are doing. This is not a test. There’s no test. No test. Family Member: Okay, he was asking when we were waiting for you. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If the treatment you’re going to give him is going to make him feel better Patient: Yes. Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
